results.title: ‘Crimes of the Future’ Review: The Horror, the Horror
results.abstract: In his latest shocker, David Cronenberg prophetically reads the signs while Léa Seydoux performs surgeries on a beatific Viggo Mortensen.

multimedia.caption: From left, Léa Seydoux, Viggo Mortensen and Kristen Stewart in “Crimes of the Future.”

results.title: ‘Benediction’ Review: A Poet’s Life, in Love and War
results.abstract: Terence Davies’s latest film is a biography of Siegfried Sassoon, whose writing about World War I changed British literature.

multimedia.caption: Jack Lowden in “Benediction,” a look at the life of the British poet Siegfried Sassoon from the director Terence Davies.

results.title: Are the Movies Liberal?
results.abstract: Everyone knows Hollywood is progressive. But look at the films it churns out. They tell another story.

results.title: Mark Rylance on ‘Jerusalem’ and the Golf Comedy ‘Phantom of the Open’
results.abstract: The acclaimed British actor explains the links between his tour de force stage turn and a recent string of subdued screen roles.

multimedia.caption: Over the years of performing, Mark Rylance said, he’s learned “there’s no bottom to the depth of insanity that will come up through me.”

results.title: The Actual Malice of the Johnny Depp Trial
results.abstract: In this post-#MeToo moment, misogyny and celebrity go hand in hand.

multimedia.caption: Even before the verdict came in, Depp had already won. What had looked like a clear-cut case of domestic violence had devolved into a “both sides” melodrama.

results.title: ‘Fire Island’ Review: Oh, the Summer Nights
results.abstract: The quips are almost as hot as the sexual tension in Andrew Ahn and Joel Kim Booster’s loosely paced but endearing romantic comedy.

results.title: ‘Hollywood Stargirl’ Review: Starting Anew in La La Land
results.abstract: Julia Hart’s bubbly sequel picks up the story in summertime and reframes around Stargirl, a character who in the first movie was auxiliary by design.

results.title: With ‘Neptune Frost,’ How to Make an Afrofuturist Sci-Fi Musical
results.abstract: What does technological progress look like to those exploited to achieve it? The co-directors Saul Williams and Anisia Uzeyman discuss their unusual film.

results.title: For Joel Kim Booster, Making ‘Fire Island’ Was a Real Trip
results.abstract: The writer and star of “Fire Island” reflects on making the rare romantic comedy that puts gay Asian American men at its center.

multimedia.caption: Joel Kim Booster at Akbar in Los Angeles. He said that before filming started, he thought, “This is either going to change my life or it’s going to be the biggest flop of my career.”

results.title: Johnny Depp’s Win in Court Could Embolden Others, Lawyers Say
results.abstract: The actor’s victory against his ex-wife Amber Heard in one of the highest profile defamation cases to go to trial could inspire others to try their luck with juries.

results.title: George Shapiro, Talent Manager Who Pushed for ‘Seinfeld,’ Dies at 91
results.abstract: He left his job as an agent in the 1970s to guide the careers of Jerry Seinfeld, Carl Reiner and other comics.
des_facet: Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee (Web-Original Program)

multimedia.caption: George Shapiro in 2019 with Jerry Seinfeld and Eddie Murphy. “The bond between George and I was, we thought show business was the greatest thing invented by man, and we couldn’t get enough,” Mr. Seinfeld said.

results.title: In ‘The Royal,’ a Life Is Rebuilt in Spite of Everything
results.abstract: A film tells the true story of Willie Aikens, a World Series star for the Kansas City Royals whose life was derailed by drugs — and prison — before he pieced it back together.

multimedia.caption: In 1980, Willie Aikens of the Kansas City Royals did something no one had done before him: Had two multihomer games in one World Series. His career soon unraveled because of drugs.
In 1980, Willie Aikens of the Kansas City Royals did something no one had done before him: Had two multihomer games in one World Series. His career soon unraveled because of drugs.
